column3: Evidence

column1: Video
column3: Video explians what it is intented to do, but could have provided example commands in GIT and GITS to differentiate the extent to GITS simplifies our job

column1: Workload is spread over the whole team (one team member is often Xtimes more productive than the others...but nevertheless, here is a track record that everyone is contributing a lot)
column3: https://github.com/bhavesh242/GITS/graphs/contributors. There is a huge descrepency in the person with highest number of commits and person with lowest number of commits

column1: Number of commits
column3: Over 214+ commits in the moth of September and October, spread over 10 teammates. But commits are done together in a few days (7 days in total), doesn't show an incremental development

column1: Number of commits: by different people
column3: Commits count are ranging between 4 to 54. Few of the teammates have significantly low commits count

column1: Issues reports: there are many
column3: 17 issues have been raised, opened and closed in 2 days

column1: Issues are being closed
column3: all issues closed in 1 day

column1: DOI badge: exists
column3: Badges exist

column1: Docs: doco generated, format not ugly
column3: some mistakes in doc. Creating a new branch is wrongly mentioned in doc. Found difficult to start with as it doesnt mention dependency with GIT anywhere

column1: Docs: what: point descriptions of each class/function (in isolation)
column3: Decently documented

column1: Docs: how: for common use cases X,Y,Z mini-tutorials showing worked examples on how to do X,Y,Z
column3: No mini tutorials or worked examples

column1: Docs: why: docs tell a story, motivate the whole thing, deliver a punchline that makes you want to rush out and use the thing
column3: not convincing enough to make me move from GIT

column1: Docs: short video, animated, hosted on your repo. That convinces people why they want to work on your code.
column3: Nothing related to this in the video
